div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: THE RUSSIAN STRIKES.
div.p: TWO KILLED AT WARSAW.
St. Petersburg Quiet

div.head: CIRCULAR OF THE HOLY SYNOD.
div.p: St Petersburg. January 28
There are 100,000 strikers both at Warsaw No newspapers are being published The bakeries at Warsaw are almost entirely without bread. (Reuter)
LIBAU January 28.
The strikers here have destroyed the tele-graph poles. They attempted to raid the bakeries but were dispersed by the troops who were reinforced. (Reuter.)
Two killed were killed in a conflict between the police and the strikers. (Havas.)
St. Petersburg, January 29.
The city is quiet. (Havas.)

Warsaw, January 29. Seventy arrests have been made. (Havas.) St. Petersburg, January 29. A circular from the Holy Synod to the Chruch says that the strikes have been instigated by enemies at home and abread and have been led by a crinimal priest. They have broken out at a moment when all should cooperate to protect their Fatherland. The object of Russia's enemies is to produce a civil war and to prevent reinforcements being sent to the Manchurian Army; It concludes with an appeal for obedience to the Emperor and to God's commands, and a warning against advisers with who are in the pay of Russia's enemies. Moscow and our city are quiet. (Reuter.) Warsaw, January 29. The strike here has extended, The strikers have stopped the traincars and traffic is practically suspended. (Reuter).

div.head: ANGLOPHOBE PROCLAMATIONS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 28. "The official Messenge" and the semi-official "Journal de St. Petersburg” printed yesterday, as having been received by the General Staff, the same news regarding the subject of the Moscow proclamations as we have already published. It is stated that Sir C. Hardiage has again protested, and in a stronger manner. (Reuter.)

Moscow, January 28. The Chief of the Police yesterday informed the British Counsel that, on his own responsibility, he is leaving the posters standing for two days longer, in order to assist in tiding over the present difficulties The Consul has telegraphed to Sir C. Hardinge. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCO-RUSSIAN ALLIANCE. ATTACKED IN FRENCH CHAMBER.
div.p: Paris, January 28. Chamber of Deputies.—M. Ronvier's reference to the Russian Alliance was greeted with an uproar, M. Jaures and others protested against the continuance of an alliance with a Government of murderers, etc., etc. M.Delcasse repeatedly intervened imploring the speakers to moderate their expressions for the sake of the name and interest, of France. He added that they should never forget that this alliance had given security to France. A vote of confidence was carried by 4lO votes to 107. (Reuter.)
Paris, January 28. Replying to the Socialists in the Chamber of Deputies, M. Delcasse spoke in support of the alliance with Russia. (Havas.)

div.head: NORTH SEA ENQUIRY.
div.p: Paris, January 29. The North Sea Commission has been hitting during the week with open doors. It examined the Hull fishermen, who gave flat denials to the presence of Japuncso torpedo-boat. (R.)

div.head: ITALIAN NAVAL ESTIMATES.
div.p: The Italian Naval Estimates show an increase of £45,000 on account of the formation of a reserve fleet and a naval station in America. (Reuter.)

div.head: HUNGARIAN ELECTIONS.
div.p: Budapest, January 28. The Government has been completely overthrown at the elections. (Reuter.)

div.head: MANCHURIA RENEWED FIGHTING. VILLAGE TAKEN AND ABANDONED BY RUSSIANS
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 28. General Knropatkin cables that the Japanese counter-attack was repulsed. At 7 p.m. on the 25th inst., after a desperate fight, the Russians entered the large, and strongly entrenched, village of Sandepu. During the day, 100 Japanese prisoners were captured. The offensive was resumed on 26th inst., the enemy’s entrenchments at Sha-Ho-Pu being occupied. Attempts to dislodge the Russians were repulsed At 4 p.m. the Japanese were re-attacking the positions at Sandepu. (R.) St. Petersburg, January 29. General Sakbaroff wires yesterday that the Russians continued their attack on Sandepu with tho object of demolishing the principal Japanese redoubt. Their cavalry put to flight several columns of Japanese from Heikoutai, and captured 50 prisoners. It is stated here that the Russians had 1,000 casualties during the assault on Sandepu. (Reuter.)

London, January 28. Reuter’s correspondent with Kuroki states that the weather is awful. A combination of frost, snow, and fog is frustrating a general engagement and entailing the most severe sufferings on any troops camping in the open. (Reuter.)

Tokyo, January 28. Oyama reports that the Russian Army Corps on the right bank of the Hun-Ho advanced on the 25th inst., and was attacked by the Japanese on the 26th. The Russians were defeated at Chenchiehpao. Fighting was proceeding at Heikoutai. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, January 28. General Kuropatkin telegraphs that the Russians have captured the village of Sandepu. (Havas.)
St. Petersburg, January 29. General Sakharoff telegraphs that the Russians have abandoned the village of Sandepu. Their losses were 24 officers aud 1,600 men. (Havas.)

Mukden, January 29. The Japanese have fallen back. The Russian cavalry advanced on their lines 10 miles. The firing continued on the right flank on the 27th inst., but it does not seem to have developed on the centre or eastern flank, and ceased altogether on the 28th. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, January 29. General Mistchenko has been wouuded in the leg, but remains at the front. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, January 29. General. Sakharoff telegraphs that, after occupying on the 26th the greater part of Sandepu, the Russians encountered a strong redoubt with a triple row of artificial obstacles. Seeing the impossibity of carrying the redoubt without a previous bombardment, the Russians evacuated Sandepu, where it was impossible to remain without risking a defeat. They violently bombarded Sandepu and the redoubt during the 27th and 28th. (Reuter.)

Tokyo, January 29. Marshal Oyama reports that, as a result of Saturday’s fighting, the Russians at Hei-kou-tai and Liv-tia-kou reunited on the right bank of the Hun Ho; The Japanese captured 500 Russians.(Reuter.)

div.head: NILE TOURISTS.
div.p: The following passengers left Shellal yesterday by the P.S. "Prince Abbas" Mr. and Huckel, Mr. G. Chdix D'Eat-Ange, Mrs. Loid-law, Hon. Florence Heneage, Capt. Jackson, Mr. and Mrs E. R. Ackerman, Col. and Mrs. W. Clark, Prof. Dr. Martin and Mrs. Philip-son, Mrs. Joseph S. Chahoon, Mrs. R., Miss and Miss Elsie Jo-eph. Mr. E. C., Mrs. M.E. C., Misses Mary E. C. and Edith L and Mr. John H. Willis, Mr. Titica, Miss C.E. and Miss E.K. Davidson, Mr. W.E. and Miss Grace Chess. The following passengers left Cairo on Friday by the "Hatasoo”: Mr. W. H. Kirkpatrick, Mayor G. von Hechhitz, Mr. Kappell Mr. Kappell, Mr. A. Hudd, Mr. G. Wain Wright, Mr. R. H. Mason, Mrs. R. Mason. Miss M. Grout, Mr. J. C. Taite, Mrs. Taite, Mrs. Chas. and Miss C. Tapp, Mr. Fritz and Mrs. Margarithe Pohlmann, Mr. Paul and Mrs. Johanna Wiesenthal, Dr. J. Ward Lawson, Mr. W. G. Graham, Miss Kempson, Miss Hughes, Mr. Nethe, Mr. Wehmann, Mrs. M G. Foster, Miss Isabel Bellman, Mr. and Mrs. R Ghika, Miss Ghika, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh White, Miss White, Mme. I. Dumaillet, Mr W. Huttner, Mr. G. Zeidler, Mr. and Mrs. H F. Longmore, Mrs. H. M. Mason, Mr. Ludovic, Mr. L. Mann.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the Central position. Under English management. (Reuter.)

div.head: Erratum
div.p: In our Saturday’s note on the thieft of the LE. 8,000 from the Mahmal train, the Arabic proverb quoted was misprinted. It should have been Yisraqu maken Nebi. H.M.S. "E-sex” left Alexandria yesterday heading for Port Said and Corfu, where she will coal and indulge in target practice until she returns to Alexandria to embark the Duke and Duchess of Connaught.

div.head: State Railways
div.p: There was no luncheon-car on Friday on the midday train from Alexandria to Cairo. A notice was posted up in the train to the effect that the car was under repair and that there was no other available to replace it.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: From the 1st to 26th inst. 22,368 tons of coal were imported, as against 31,176 for the same period last year. Newcastle sent 5,833 tons, Welsh districts 11,927 tons, Scotch 2,575 tons, Yorkshire 1,786 tons, and other districts 247 tons.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 8 vessels passed through the Canal on the 25th inst., 4 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Italian. The receipts for the day were frs. 261,093.97. The total receipts from 1st to 25th inst. amounted to frs. 9,115,174.93.

div.head: Concert
div.p: Professor Henri Felix, the well-known local pianist and composer, is giving a concert at the New Khedivial Hotel on Saturday next, at 9.15 p.m. He will be assisted in an excellent programme by Mrs. Fred Cree and Messrs. H. and L Suzan.

div.head: Armenian Benevolent Society
div.p: A theatrical performance for the benefit of the Armenian Benevolent Society at Alexandria will be given on Friday next, the 3rd proxo, at the Zizinia Theatre. The Khedive has graciously consented to give his patronage to the performance.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: Lumieres et Tenebres, the latest production at the Alhambra, is a spectacular play which should have a long run. It is supported by a excellent variety entertainment. A favorite with Alhambra habitues, Mila Liza Cariola, makes her rentree this evening.

div.head: H. M. Transport "Sicilia”
div.p: (Capt. G. H. C. Weston, R. N. R.) arrived at Port Said early on Saturday morning from Bombay, and left at noon for Southampton direct. The troops on board, consisting of details, numbered 1,206 of all ranks. A draft of 100 men embarked at p.r Said. Major J. R Carte, R. G. A., is the officer commanding. The North German Lloyd’s S.S. “Ho-henzollern” arrived at Alexandria today from Naples and Marseilles at about 2 p.m. She brought about eighty first class passengers for Egypt, including a number of distinguished visitors. They expect to catch the 4.25 afternoon express for Cairo, otherwise a special train may be arranged for. The "Hohenzollern" is leaving Alexandria on Wednesday and will return here again on the 14th proxo.

div.head: "The Pirates of Penzance."
div.p: The date of the first performance of the above has been advanced to the 17th of February to suit the convenience of H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught, who has promised to honor the performance with his presence. H.H. the Khedive has also bestowed his patronage, and that of the Right Hon. the Earl of Cromer and of Major General Slade has likewise been obtained. The theatricals will thus assume the dignity of an important society function. The date of the opening of the box office will shortly be announced.

div.head: AN ADVANTAGEOUS TIME TABLE
div.p: It is often very difficult for business men, employees, etc., to find an hour or two for study outside their business hours. Thanks to their excellent arrangements, an hour can always be found at the Berlitz Schools for English, French, German, Italian, and other lessons, to suit the convenience of everyone, as the hours can be chosen by the student himself. This special advantage is much appreciated, as are the numerous other facilities offered by this celebrated institute.

div.head: NITRATE AND PHOSPHATE CONCESSION.
div.p: Mr. Henry J. Monson, of the Nitrate and Phosphate Quarries, who is at present in London, has appointed a chemist, who is the son of a noted Scotch farmer, also another Scotchman, a chemist, assayer, and mining engineer, for the works. The machinery for grinding phosphates, etc. is being shipped , and a large steam tug is leaving England by sea, hugging the coast. Mr. Monson hopes to be in Egypt shortly.

div.head: TEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner " Menes " arrived here yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Moss liner " Tabor ” passed Scilly on Saturday last bound for Liverpool. The S.S. " Nitocris” arrived here yesterday morning from Glasgow, via Gibraltar and Malta, with passengers, general cargo, and coal. The Moss liner " Rameses" sailed from , Liverpool on Tuesday afternoon, and is due here about the l0th proxo, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT
div.p: (the journey up-river) The departure of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught from Cairo took place at 7 p.m. on Friday night, Skander Pasha Fehmy accompanying them as far as Luxor. An empty train acted as pilot to avoid any risk of accident, and the special train was composed of six carriages, in the third of which were the Duke and Duchess. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, Lord and Lady Cromer, Dr. Rucker-Jenisch, Graf von Wedel, General Slade, C. B, Adly Pasha Yaghen, Mansfield Pasha, Mr. P. Machell, and many other distinguished persons were on the platform to bid the Duke end Duchess good-bye. El Lews Lord Edward Cecil Pesha, D.S.0, is accompanying their Royal Highnesses to the Sudan. On Friday H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught called upon Dr. Rucker Jenisch on the occasion of the birthday of the German Emperor.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT LUXOR.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught arrived at Luxor to-day at 10.55 a.m. A number of official personages were on the platform awaiting the arrival of the Royal train. Among them I noticed the British consular agent, Mr. Hazell, Mr. Western, the Moudir of Keneh and the Mondirieh officials, M. Legrain and Mr. Quibell, of the Antiquities Department, and others, with whom the Duke wes pleased to exchange salutations. On leaving the station, the Duke and Duchess of Connaught drove to the temple, over which they were shown by Mr. Quibell and M. Legrain. Their Royal Highnsesses spent about half an hour in inspecting the ruins, in which the Princesses took especial interest. They did not proceed to Karnak, as was intended, owing to the delay caused to the Royal train by the “train de luxe," which stopped for about an hour and a half on its up journey and prevented the Royal train from arriving here at the scheduled time. After visiting the temple, the Royal party went on board the S.S. “Ibis,” which was anchored near the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company's landing-stage^ which Mr. Simpson, the company’s agent, had tastefully decorated in honor of the occasion. Tho “Ibis” left on its journey to Assouan at 12.15 p.m. Luxor station was prettily decorated and the streets were lined by large crowds of people, who were kept in order by the polios, whose arrangements were excellent. The front of the Luxor Hotel, as well as the road leading to the landing-stage, was crowded with visitors, anxious to see our Royal guests, who graciously responded to the salutations that greeted them.

div.head: EDFON PASSED.
div.p: The S.S. “Ibis,” with the Duke and Duchess of Connaught on board, passed Edfou last night at 10 o'olock on the southward journey. On Saturday morning, H.H. the Khedive received M. de la Bonlinitra, who presented General de Nifgrier; the Hon. John W. Riddle, who presented Messr. James Speyer, F. Jackerman, and Richard Gottheil. In the afternoon his Highness received H.H. Prince Hussein and Count Gabriel de Zogheb.

div.head: AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN BALL
div.p: The ball given at the Khedivial Hotel on Saturday by the Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society at Alexandria was, in every sense of the word, a brilliant success. There was a very large and representative gathering present, including all the leaders of local society. The scene presented in the magnificent ball-room at the height of the ball was animated and pretty, some of the fair dancers being garbed in exquisite "creations,” which it is beyond the power of a “mere man" to describe. The ball, however, was notable for the magnificence of the ladies' toilettes and the number of gentlemen present bedecked with decorations. It would be futile to attempt to give an idea of the number of well-known people who filled the ball-room and the saloons of the hotel We will confine ourselves to giving a few of the names of the members of the English colony present: Lady and Mr. Blomfield, Mr. E. B. Gould, I.S.O., and Mrs. Gould-Brigen. Bullock, C.B„ Captain Farquhar and the officers of H.M.S. "Essex," Lieut.-Col. McCracken and the officers of the Royal Berkshire Regiment, officers of the Royal Malta Art tillery, Mr. W. P. Chataway, Mr. R. C. Abdy, Mr. and Mrs. Preston, Mr. P. G. Freeman, Mr. and Miss Lang Anderson, Dr. and Mrs. Morrison, Mr. and Mrs. John Rows Mrs. Rees, Miss Barker, Miss Alderson, Miss Pringle, Mr., Mrs. and Miss MunGavin, etc. H.B. the Governor was present, as were also the Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent, the Consular General, and several other members of the Consular Corps. The hall was better attended than ever before. An "incident" between two members of the a Syrian community, which threatened to mar the gaiety of the evening, was happily closed, by the intervention of third parties, and a duel was averted.

div.head: RUSSIAN CRUISER IN CANAL BOUND FOR DJIBOUTI WITH PROVISIONS.
div.p: The Russian armed cruiser "Irtich” (Capt. Ergomicheff), flying the naval Bag, arrived at Port Said on Friday from Liban direct, and entered the Canal on Saturday for Djibouti, she has a crew of 223. Our Suez Correspondent telegraphed on Saturday that the "Irtich” had arrived there and anchored in the bay. She was to have sailed in the evening. (From Our Correspondent).
Suez, Monday. The Russian cruiser “ Irtich" which was formerly a Hamburg-American liner, sailed at 12.30 p.m. today for Djibouti, taking with certain provisions.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE DYING OUT.
div.p: The report for the week ending Saturday shows that one death only has occurred from-this disease, at Khantoon Bibeh Markas, while 275 serum inoculations have been made during the month. The epidemic is evidently dying away faster than was expected.

div.head: THE SAKHARA AFFAIR.
div.p: Owing to the fact that no less than three processes were pending with reference to the recent assault at Sakhara, the French visitors having lodged a complaint against Mr. Howard Carter at the British Consulate, while Mr. Howard Carter lodged one against them at the French Consulate and the visitors had also brought an action against the ghaffir of the Antiquites Service before the Native Tribunals, the Government has decided to simplify matters. A commission has therefore been appointed, consisting of Mr. De Hultze, Maitre Molten, and the Chief of the Native Perqoet, who will enquire into the affair and issne a report This isolation seems an extremely practical one.

div.head: THE BOURSE CASE.
div.p: Judgment was given at the Mixed Coart, Alexandria, this morning in the case brought by Messrs. Boutros Brothers, the well-known Syrian capitalists, against the Khedivial Bourse, the Alexandria Stock brokers Associations, and the Produce Brokers Association. Judgment was given against the plaintiffs. The details of this important judgment will be found on page 4 of today’s issue.

div.head: THE ORIENT BANK.
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent writes respecting the Orient Bank, which is about to establish branches in Egypt. The Orient Bank intends to obtain a great position in the Levant, and in an interview I had recently with a well-known German financier, he said that the Bank expected to' do great things when it came to Egypt. M. L Zarifi, M. E. Bugenides, and M. Eliases have been appointed members of the board oi the Constantinople branch of the Orient Bank. It is said also that M. Neef of the Deutsche Bank, has been appointed manager of the same brauch. M. Neef, who was formerly sectioual chief at the Imperial Ottoman Bank, is very well-known in our city. He accompanied M. Gwinuer, general manager of the Deutsche Bank, when that gentleman came to Constantinople in connection with the unification of the Ottoman Debt.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: The concert given by the Committee of Fetes at the Savoy Hotel on Friday night was a great success. M. Nani, who has a very powerful baritone voice which he knows how to use, was loudly applauded for his splendid rendering of the prologue to Pagliacci, and Mme. Bracale gave a fine interpretation of Elisabeth's Aria in Don Carlos. Mascagni's "Hymn to the Sun” was also well given by the orchestra and chorus. Altogether the concert was a thorough success. Saturday evening's dance at the Savoy was attended with the usual success, all the Savoy habitues being there. The Restaurant was full both for dinner and sapper. We noticed Mrs. Muriel Campbell and a party of 6, Mr. Thubron and a party of 7, Mr. Charles Royle entertaining 6 guests, Mrs. Curtis and 5 guests, Mr. and Mrs. Livingston and 2 guests, Mr. and Mrs. Faber, M.P. and a party, Mrs. K. Simon and 6 guests, Fabricius Pasha and Madame Fabricins; Mr. Coats and a large party, Mr. Elliot-Smith and a party, etc. Owing to the ever-increasing success of the Savoy dances, the management have decided to give an extra small dance on Tuesday, 7th proxo. There will also be a bal poudre and costume at the hotel on Shrove Tuesday.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE.
div.p: The small dance given at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel last Thursday was, as usual, a great success and showed that the season in Cairo was at its height. At dinner-time the splendid restaurant was overcrowded and it was difficult to obtain a table. Dancing began at half-past nine and was very animated. At 12 o’clock the majority of those present part took of sapper, which is quite a Ghesireh speciality. We will not attempt to mention the names of the guests as it would take up too much space, but we may say that the best of Cairo society and the most prominent of the visitors attended the dance. Next Thursday's dance promises to be even more successdul as already a good many dinners have been ordered for that evening.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Empress Eugenie intends paying a visit to Assouan. The Mistress of Donegall, who is among the latest arrivals in Cairo, is a charming and one of the sweetest singers in society. Her son, the present Marquis, is just over a year old, and was born when his father was over eighty years of age. Lady Donegall's marriage in 1902 was a notable function. Lord Stratchcona, her distinguished compatriot, gave the bride away. The Earl and Countess of Lendesborough entertained a distinguished party at dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, the guests including General, Mrs. and Miss Blade, Sir William Garstio, Mr. Marshall, Mr. George Chobnondeley. Mr. Vinemit Corbet, Mr. Locket, Miss G. Harley, Miss Dunn Villa, and the Hon. A Stanley. Mr. Edgar Anderson also entertained a party of friends to dinner, including Mr. Price, M.P., Mr. Forretier Walker, Mr. Constantinidis, Mr. Paravicini, and Mr. Wyatt, at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening. The P. and O.S.S. "Marmora," due at Port Said this week, a number of distingnished passengers on board for Egypt, including Earl and Countess Howe, Sir Edward and Lady Colebrooke, Gen. Sir R. Biddulph, and Sir. Ernest Cassel. The Earl and Countess of Carnarvop are passengers for Ceylon by the same steamer.

We regret to state that Countess Howe is still an invalid and had to be carried in an invalid chair from her carriage to the train at Victoria station, London, on Saturday week. Lord Howe and Mr. Churchill, M.P., were at the station to see her off. Earl Howe joined the Countess on Wednesday last at Paris and they both then left for Egypt. Sir Ernest Cassel travelled in the same train en route for Egypt He has reserved his usual magnificent suite at the Savoy.

With the arrival of Sir Ernest Cassel and Mr. William Waldorf Astor, the Savoy will house four of the great millionaires of the world, for Mr. Astor is the richest ground landlord in the world, and is reputed to be worth £40,000,000, while the Duke of Devon-shire and Sir Thomas Lipton, who are also at the Savoy, are respectively worth £10,000,000 and £5,000,000. That well-known figure in London society, the Clerk Marshal and Chief Equerry to the King, Mqjor-General Sir Stanley da Astel Calvert Clarke, G.C.V.O, K.C.V.O., C.M.G., left Marseilles last week en route for Egypt. Mr. Harold Spender, Editor of the "Westminster Gazette,” and Mrs. Spender, who are in Cairo, are going as for as Khartoum. Count Bolesta von Kosziedrowski returned to Cairo from Alexandria yesterday. A marriage has been arranged and will shortly take place between Miss Nana Maeredie of Sydney, Australia, and Mr. J. W. Williamson of Cairo.

On Saturday afternoon last, Mrs. Carton de Wiart gave a small and very smart “at home” at her charming house et Kasrel-Doubere. The arrangements were perfect in every respect. A dainty tea was served on the large verandah overlooking the garden, where the Blue Hungarians played interesting selection of aire in their best style. Among the number of guests were Mrs. and Miss Rblyle, Lady Willcocks, Mr. and Mrs. Langley, Dr. and Mrs. Nolan, Lady Rogers, Captain and Mrs. Westropp, Izzct Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalegleish, Mrs. Branyate, Mr. and Mra Stone, Miss Hanson, Captain Mac Lean, and many others. Col.and Mrs. de Plante came down to Alexandria, today after spending about a week at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo. Mr. and Mrs. Watmouth, of New York,have returned to Cairo after a long trip on the Nile in the steam dahabieh "Mena.” Lieut Colonel H. S, McGill. R.AM.C., will be on promotion, probably be posted to Egypt. Colonel G. P. Gorringe, C.M.G., D.S.O., R.E is shown in this month's “Army list" as still borne on the establishment of the Egyptian Army. This is clearly an error, for we announced some time ago his resignation of his Egyptian appointment, and it is announced from Aldershot that he has joined the Army Corps , there—as it has now become again— as Officer in Charge of Public Lands within the area of the command, vice Major F. V. Jeffreys, who has left the station.

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid amp; Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
